NPA and City/Town Search Results | accessdate = 2007-01-18}}</ref> |website = [http://www.ci.gardena.ca.us/ ci.gardena.ca.us] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 06-28168 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 1660664 |footnotes = }} <!-- Infobox ends -->
'''Gardena''' is a city in [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]], [[California]], [[United States]]. The population was 58,829 at the 2010 census, up from 57,746 at the 2000 census.
==Geography== Gardena is located at {{Coord|33|53|37|N|118|18|28|W|type:city}} (33.893615, -118.307841).{{GR|1}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|5.9|sqmi|km2}}, over 99% of which is land.
Gardena is bordered by [[Athens, California|Athens]] on the north, the [[Los Angeles]] neighborhood of [[Harbor Gateway, Los Angeles, California|Harbor Gateway]] on the east and south, [[Torrance, California|Torrance]] on the southwest, [[Alondra Park, California|Alondra Park]] on the west, and [[Hawthorne, California|Hawthorne]] on the northwest.
==History== Based on archaeological findings, [[Tongva people|Tongva Indians]] hunted and fished in the area of today's Gardena.<ref name=Gardena>{{cite book|last=Gardena Heritage Committee|title=Gardena|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|page=7|year=2006|isbn=9780738546766}}</ref> The Tongva Indians â also known as Gabrielino Indians â are probably descendants of those who crossed from Asia to North America around 10,000 years ago.<ref name=Gardena/>
In 1784, three years after the foundation of [[Los Angeles]], [[Manuel Dominguez#Juan Jose Dominguez|Juan Jose Dominguez]] (1736â1809), a [[Spain|Spanish]] soldier who arrived in [[San Diego]], [[California]] in 1769 with [[Fernando Rivera y Moncada]], in recognition of his military service, received the roughly {{convert|43000|acre|km2|adj=on}} Spanish land grant, the [[Rancho San Pedro]]. Part of this land contained what became known as Gardena Valley.<ref name=Gardena/> After the [[American Civil War]] veterans bought parts of the land, soon ranchers and farmers followed suit.<ref name=Gardena/> Union Army Major General [[William Rosecrans|William Starke Rosecrans]] in 1869 bought {{convert|16000|acre|km2}}. The "Rosecrans Rancho," was bordered by what later was Florence Avenue on the north, Redondo Beach Boulevard on the south, Central Avenue on the east, and Arlington Avenue on the west. The Rosecrans property was sub divided and sold in the early 1870s. One of those became the {{convert|650|acre|km2|adj=on}} [[Dominique Amestoy|Amestoy Ranch]]. Gardena proper began in 1887 when the Pomeroy & Harrison real estate developers subdivided the ranch, and-anticipating that the coming of the Los Angeles and Redondo Railway. Civil War veteran Spencer Roane Thorpe is credited with starting the first settlement in Gardena in 1887.<ref name=Gardena/> Railroads put Gardena on the map following a real estate boom in the Los Angeles area in the 1880s.<ref name=Gardena/> Some believe the city was named for its reputation for being the only "green spot" in the dry season between Los Angeles and the sea.<ref name=Gardena/> Because of its acres of berries, the city was dubbed "Berryland".<ref name=Gardena/> The Strawberry Day Festival and Parade was held each May annually.<ref name=Gardena/> The berry industry suffered at the time of [[World War I]] as other crops were supported by the [[war economy]].<ref name=Eight>Gardena, p. 8</ref> [[Japanese American]]s settled in Gardena throughout its history.<ref>[http://www.colapublib.org/history/gardena/faq.html#q5 Frequently Asked Questions: Gardena] [[County of Los Angeles Public Library]]. Retrieved on March 27, 2010.</ref>
The only way Gardena could protect itself from a heavy county tax imposed on a planned project at a park site was to incorporate.<ref name=Eight/> The City of Gardena became incorporated on September 11, 1930.<ref name=Eight/>
==Demographics== {{USCensusPop | 1940=5909 | 1950=14405 | 1960=35943 | 1970=41021 | 1980=45165 | 1990=49847 | 2000=57746 | 2010=58829 | footnote=source:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.census.gov/prod/www/abs/decennial/index.html |title=CENSUS OF POPULATION AND HOUSING (1790-2000) |publisher=[[U.S. Census Bureau]] |accessdate=2010-07-30}}</ref> }} ===2010=== The [[2010 United States Census]]<ref>{{USCensus-2010CA}}</ref> reported that Gardena had a population of 58,829. The [[population density]] was 10,030.0 people per square mile (3,872.6/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of Gardena was 14,498 (24.6%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 14,352 (24.4%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 348 (0.6%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 15,400 (26.2%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 426 (0.7%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 11,136 (18.9%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 2,669 (4.5%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 22,151 persons (37.7%).
The Census reported that 58,035 people (98.7% of the population) lived in households, 122 (0.2%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 672 (1.1%) were institutionalized.
There were 20,558 households, out of which 7,199 (35.0%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 8,782 (42.7%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 3,931 (19.1%) had a female householder with no husband present, 1,486 (7.2%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 1,085 (5.3%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 104 (0.5%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 5,142 households (25.0%) were made up of individuals and 1,921 (9.3%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.82. There were 14,199 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (69.1% of all households); the average family size was 3.39.
The population was spread out with 13,410 people (22.8%) under the age of 18, 5,353 people (9.1%) aged 18 to 24, 16,656 people (28.3%) aged 25 to 44, 15,086 people (25.6%) aged 45 to 64, and 8,324 people (14.1%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37.9 years. For every 100 females there were 92.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.8 males.
There were 21,472 housing units at an average density of 3,660.8 per square mile (1,413.5/kmÂ²), of which 9,852 (47.9%) were owner-occupied, and 10,706 (52.1%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 1.3%; the rental vacancy rate was 4.6%. 28,585 people (48.6% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 29,450 people (50.1%) lived in rental housing units.
===2000=== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 57,746 people, 20,324 households, and 14,023 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 9,921.3 inhabitants per square mile (3,830.9/kmÂ²). There were 21,041 housing units at an average density of 3,615.0 per square mile (1,395.9/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of the city was 23.82% [[Race (United States Census)|White]], 25.99% [[Race (United States Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.64% [[Race (United States Census)|Native American]], 26.82% [[Race (United States Census)|Asian]], 0.73% [[Race (United States Census)|Pacific Islander]], 16.94% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 5.05% from two or more races. 31.82% of the population were [[Hispanics in the United States|Hispanic]] or [[Race (United States Census)|Latino]] of any race.
There were 20,324 households out of which 33.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 44.5% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 18.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 31.0% were non-families. 25.5% of all households were made up of individuals and 8.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.80 and the average family size was 3.38.
In the city the population was spread out with 25.8% under the age of 18, 8.7% from 18 to 24, 32.3% from 25 to 44, 20.9% from 45 to 64, and 12.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females there were 95.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 91.4 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $38,988, and the median income for a family was $44,906. Males had a median income of $32,951 versus $29,908 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $17,263. About 12.3% of families and 15.7% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 22.3% of those under age 18 and 10.1% of those age 65 or over.
==Government and infrastructure== ===Local government=== The [[Gardena Office of Economic Development]] is a department of the city government. It aids employers in filling a variety of jobs customized to their specific needs. It also helps potential employers in setting up business enterprises.
The [[Gardena Police Department]] is the primary law enforcement agency in the City. The Police Department has 93 sworn police officers, 24 full-time support staff, and 33 part-time employees. There are reserve, volunteer, and explorer programs. The current Chief of Police is Edward Medrano, appointed in 2007. Radio communications and the 9-1-1 call center are handled by the [[South Bay Regional Public Communications Authority]].
===County representation=== The [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] operates the Curtis Tucker Health Center in [[Inglewood, California|Inglewood]] and the Torrance Health Center in [[Harbor Gateway, Los Angeles, California|Harbor Gateway]], [[Los Angeles]], near [[Torrance, California|Torrance]] and serving Gardena.<ref>"[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phn/docs/HealthCenter/torrance.pdf Torrance Health Center]." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 18, 2010.</ref><ref>"[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phn/docs/HealthCenter/inglewood.pdf Curtis Tucker Health Center]." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 18, 2010.</ref>
===State representation=== In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]] Gardena is located in the [[California's 25th State Senate district|25th]] [[California State Senate|Senate]] District, represented by Democrat Roderick D. Wright, and in the 51st [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] District, represented by Democrat [[Curren D. Price Jr.]].
===Federal representation=== Gardena is located in [[California's 35th congressional district]], which has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|Cook PVI]] of D +33<ref>{{cite web | title = Will Gerrymandered Districts Stem the Wave of Voter Unrest? | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://www.clcblog.org/blog_item-85.html | accessdate = 2008-02-10}}</ref> and is represented by Democrat [[Maxine Waters]].
The [[United States Postal Service]] operates the Gardena Post Office at 1455 West Redondo Beach Boulevard,<ref>"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/15786?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Gardena Post Office Location - GARDENA]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref> the South Gardena Post Office at 1103 West Gardena Boulevard,<ref>"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/63390?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Gardena Post Office Location - SOUTH GARDENA]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref> and the Alondra Post Office at 14028 Van Ness Avenue.<ref>"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/12115?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Gardena Post Office Location - ALONDRA]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref>
The [[National Transportation Safety Board]] operates the Gardena Aviation Field Office in [[Harbor Gateway, Los Angeles, California|Harbor Gateway]], [[Los Angeles]]; it is the regional headquarters of the NTSB Aviation Western Region.<ref>"[http://www.ntsb.gov/abt_ntsb/regions/aviation.htm Regional Offices: Aviation]." [[National Transportation Safety Board]]. Retrieved on May 15, 2010.</ref>
===Transportation=== The city operates the [[Gardena Municipal Bus Lines]].

[[National Stores Inc.]], which operates the Factory 2-U and the Fallas Paredes brands, has its headquarters in the [[Harbor Gateway, Los Angeles, California|Harbor Gateway]] area of [[Los Angeles]],<ref>"[http://www.factory2-u.com/contactus.php Contact Us]." National Stores. Retrieved on February 24, 2010.</ref> located near the City of Gardena.<ref>"[http://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/2008/08/11/daily7.html Fallas Paredes expanding local presence]." ''[[Austin Business Journal]]''. Monday August 11, 2008. Retrieved on February 24, 2010.</ref>
===Top employers=== According to the City's 2009 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report,<ref name="cafr2009">[http://www.ci.gardena.ca.us/PDFs/Departments/administrativeservices/cafr/stat2009.pdf City of Gardena CAFR]</ref> the top employers in the city are:

==Education== ===Primary and secondary schools=== ====Public schools==== [[File:GardenaHSLosAngelesCA.jpg|thumb|[[Gardena High School]] in [[Harbor Gateway, Los Angeles|Harbor Gateway]], [[Los Angeles]]]] Gardena is served by the [[Los Angeles Unified School District]]. The area is within Board District 7.<ref>[http://www.lausd.k12.ca.us/lausd/board/secretary/BoardDistrictMaps/2007-08%20Board%20District%207.pdf Board District 7 Map]. ''[[Los Angeles Unified School District]]''. Retrieved on November 24, 2008.</ref> As of 2008 Dr. Richard Vladovic represents the district.<ref>"[http://www.lausd.k12.ca.us/lausd/board/secretary/ Board Members]." ''[[Los Angeles Unified School District]]''. Retrieved on November 24, 2008.</ref>
Zoned elementary schools include: * 152nd Street Elementary School * 156th Street Elementary School * 186th Street Elementary School<ref>{{cite web|title=186th Street Elementary School|url=http://www.186streetschool.org/}}</ref> * Ambler Elementary School * Amestoy Elementary School * Chapman Elementary School * Denker Elementary School<ref>http://www.lausd.k12.ca.us/Denker_EL/about/schedule2.html</ref> * Gardena Elementary School (Los Angeles) * Purche Elementary School ** Some areas in Gardena have a choice among Gardens Elementary School<ref>http://sfpc.lausd.k12.ca.us/AvalonGardens/default.htm Avalon</ref> ([[Los Angeles]]), Purche, and 135th Street Elementary School (Los Angeles)
Zoned middle schools include: * Peary Middle School<ref>{{cite web|title=Peary Middle School|url=http://www.pearyms.org/}}</ref> ** Some areas in Gardena have a choice between Peary and Clay Middle School<ref>{{cite web|title=Henry Clay Middle School|url=http://www.lausd.k12.ca.us/Clay_MS/}}</ref> (Los Angeles)
Zoned high schools include: * [[Gardena High School]] (Los Angeles)
In Spring 1956, the junior high school classes stayed at the old Gardena High School while the high school classes moved into a new building. Up until the opening of the new Gardena High School, high school students held morning shifts, while junior high school students held afternoon shifts.<ref>"[http://www.pearyms.org/history.jsp?rn=1167880 Peary Middle School History]." ''Peary Junior High School''. Retrieved on April 21, 2009.</ref>
====Private schools==== The [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles]] operates Catholic schools in Gardena, including [[JunÃ­pero Serra High School (Gardena, California)|JunÃ­pero Serra High School]],<ref>"[http://www.serrahighschool.com/apps/contact/?rn=9235685 Contact Us]." ''[[JunÃ­pero Serra High School (Gardena, California)|JunÃ­pero Serra High School]]''. Retrieved on April 21, 2009.</ref> Maria Regina Catholic School (K-8),<ref>"[http://mregina.org/9Contact/contact.htm Contact Maria Regina Catholic School]." ''Maria Regina Catholic School''. Retrieved on April 21, 2009.</ref> and St. Anthony of Padua School (K-8).<ref>"[http://www.archdiocese.la/directories/schools/info.php?school_id=147 St. Anthony of Padua]." ''[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles]]''. Retrieved on April 21, 2009.</ref> Gardena Valley Christian School, a K-8 non-Catholic private school, is in Gardena.<ref>[http://www.gvcs.net/ Home]. ''Gardena Valley Christian School''. Retrieved on April 21, 2009.</ref> The Gardena Christian Academy, a PreK-2 Christian school, is in Gardena.<ref>"[http://www.gardenachristianacademy.com/contact.php Gardena Christian Academy contact information]." Gardena Christian Academy. Retrieved on December 26, 2010. "Address: Gardena Christian Academy & Preschool 16311 S. Western Ave. Gardena, CA 90247."</ref>
===Public libraries=== Gardena Mayme Dear Library, a {{convert|16000|sqft|sqm|adj=on}} building located in Gardena,<ref name="MaymeDear">"[http://www.colapublib.org/libs/gardena/ Gardena Mayme Dear Library]." ''[[County of Los Angeles Public Library]]''. Retrieved on April 21, 2009.</ref> and Masao W. Satow Library, located west of Gardena in [[Alondra Park, California|Alondra Park]] (El Camino Village), [[unincorporated area|unincorporated]] [[Los Angeles County]],<ref name="Satow">"[http://www.colapublib.org/libs/satow/ Masao W. Satow Library]." ''[[County of Los Angeles Public Library]]''. Retrieved on April 21, 2009.</ref><ref name="AlondraCDPMap">"[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US0601150&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on Alondra Park CDP, California]." [[U.S. Census Bureau]]. Retrieved on May 5, 2010.</ref> are operated by the [[County of Los Angeles Public Library]].
Wednesday Progressive Club sponsored the formation of the Gardena Library.<ref name="MaymeDear"/> In 1913 the Moneta Branch was formed.<ref name="Satow"/> In 1914 the Gardena Library became a part of the Los Angeles County Free Library system. Due to annexation the library was transferred to the Los Angeles City Library Board.<ref name="MaymeDear"/> In 1919 the Strawberry Park branch was formed.<ref name="Satow"/> In August 1951 the Gardena library came back to the county system.<ref name="MaymeDear"/> In 1958 the Strawberry Park and Moneta branches merged into the West Gardena Branch.<ref name="Satow"/> The current Gardena library building was dedicated on December 5, 1964.<ref name="MaymeDear"/> In 1969 a fire forced the West Gardena branch to go to a new location. The current Satow building, dedicated on February 26, 1977, was named after a [[Japanese American]] in the community.<ref name="Satow"/> The Gardena library received its current name on May 30, 1992 after a library volunteer, who had died prior to the renaming.<ref name="MaymeDear"/>
==Notable residents/affiliates== The following is a list of natives, residents, and other people with strong ties to the city:
* [[J.C. Agajanian]]- prominent racing promoter; owned and operated [[Ascot Park (speedway)|Ascot Park]]. * [[Paul Bannai]]- former city councilman and first Japanese American to serve in the [[California State Legislature]]. * [[Romana Acosta BaÃ±uelos]]- 34th and first [[Hispanic]] [[US Treasurer]]; founder/owner of Ramona's Mexican Food Products, one of the oldest businesses still operating in the city (founded in 1949). * [[Polly Bergen]]- actress and singer; originally from [[Tennessee]], lived in Gardena and attended [[Gardena High School]] ('''GHS''').<ref name=Images>Gardena Heritage Committee, "Images of America: Gardena," (San Francisco: Arcadia Publishing, 2006), 74-99.</ref> * [[Gary Berland]]- professional poker player, won five [[World Series of Poker]] bracelets, born and raised in Gardena. * [[Enos Cabell]]- third basemen with the [[Baltimore Orioles]] and [[Detroit Tigers]]; originally from [[Kansas]], attended GHS.<ref name=Images/> * [[Wayne Collett]]- runner, [[1972 Summer Olympics]] silver medalist in the 400 meter event; attended GHS.<ref name=Images/> * [[Dock Ellis]]- pitcher with the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]]; attended GHS.<ref name=Images/> * [[Charlie Evans (American football)|Charlie Evans]]- running back with the [[New York Giants]] and [[Washington Redskins]]; born in Gardena. * [[Robert L. Freedman]]- screenwriter and playwright; onetime resident of Gardena, attended Purche Avenue Elementary school('''PAE'''). * [[World Boxing Hall of Fame Inductees|Frankie Garcia]]- Hall of Fame boxer; resident of Gardena.<ref name=Images/> * [[Gaston Green]]- running back with the [[Los Angeles Rams]] and [[Denver Broncos]]; attended GHS.<ref name=Images/> * [[H.B. Halicki]]- actor, film maker, stuntman; business owner in Gardena and premiered his ''[[Gone in 60 Seconds (1974 film)|Gone in 60 Seconds]]'' there in 1974.<ref name=Images/> * [[Lisa Leslie]]- Olympic gold medalist and [[Los Angeles Sparks]] basketball player; born in Gardena. * [[Art Pepper]]- innovative jazz saxophonist; born in Gardena. * [[Butch Patrick]]- actor; was living in Gardena and attending PAE when he auditioned for ''[[The Munsters]]''.<ref name=Images/> * [[Paul Petersen]]- actor, novelist, activist; onetime resident of Gardena.<ref name=Images/> * [[William Rosecrans]]- [[Union Army|Union]] general, [[United States Congress|congressman]], and ambassador to [[Mexico]]; owner of and resident upon (from 1869) "Rosecrans Rancho," the foundation upon which Gardena would later emerge.<ref name=Images/> * [[George Stanich]]- [[1948 Summer Olympics]] high jumper and bronze medalist; resident of Gardena.<ref name=Images/>
